data.text: Is Carbon MTB a Good Option for BikePacking?

What if any are the pitfalls of using a carbon MTB for bike packing? I've spent several days at a time on some rugged trails and have been surprised with the ease. Any advice appreciated. I'm in the early development stage of riding somewhere far away...
In case of a crash or freezing the carbon can crack and possibly wont be fixable
data.author: Menno Pieters

data.text: crack when freezing?
data.author: Gary Butcher

data.text: Iirc : can‚Äôt even be recycled when broken ‚Ä¶
data.author: Grace N Adelaide

data.text: Single track into the Bush?
data.author: Robert Clark

data.text: bush, mountain ,old railroad trails, abandoned gold rush routes including a volcanic plateau even a cone or two.. bike packing is new to me... Seems a natural evolution
data.author: Nicholas Heller

data.text: Problem is carbon dents become fractures .. might be the wrong material for other than groomed race courses.. & having more backups in the truck when they break. But Im an old guy , used to steel bike properties.. N+1 may be the solution.. N= the bike you have +1 is get another bike. in addition.
data.author: Robert Clark

data.text: Should be just fine. The only real issue is they're difficult to repair if structurally compromised.
data.author: Jake Klamerus

data.text: I'd think riding the trails would test any frame. But I see your point. On that note it would pay to ditch the pesky tubeless set up also?
data.author: Nicholas Heller

data.text: Meh tubeless can be great too. Just different procedures to deal with flats, which will happen. Personally im old school. I run tubes, steel frame and full mech groupset. Can't go wrong with either really. It only makes a difference if you're racing in my opinion.
data.author: Jake Klamerus

data.text: certainly not a race. The longer it takes the better for filling time
data.author: Nicholas Heller

data.text: I ride with tubeless and no punctures, I love tubeless. However, I carry spare tube if I have major problems, just in case
data.author: Peter Oag

data.text: None. Carbon all the way!
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: Plastic frames have a limited lifespan due to fasion and product developments, but cannot be recycled. They are a poor choice for sustainable transport.
data.author: Nick Perkins

data.text: offset by riding mine until till it drops I hope
data.author: Nicholas Heller

data.text: Carbon isn‚Äôt plastic dude. It‚Äôs made from carbon atoms and it‚Äôs closer to ceramic. And it‚Äôs easily repaired.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: na. Fake information
data.author: Nicholas Heller

data.text: this gets into personal preference and riding style/distance. A carbon fiber bike could last one person 20 years if that is their style. But you are theoretically right that the material isn't as long-lasting as steel. But some people might only ride 1000 miles a year, and for them a carbon bike might be perfect.
data.author: Ryan Tew

data.text: With respect, that was not the point i am making. Most (certainly not all) get replaced due to fashion ('must have the latest' culture) or because groupset spare parts become hard to find (product developments). When this happens, and it usually does, a steel or aluminium frame can be readily recycled. That was all.
data.author: Nick Perkins

data.text: bicycles get recycled not usually by traditional recycling, but by being handed down to newer or younger riders. I doubt, though I don't have evidence, that carbon bikes, aluminum or steel either, are very often actually recycled in any traditional recycling way.
data.author: Ryan Tew

data.text: There are lots of carbon mountain bikes used for hard core racing,etc. We have carbon gravel bikes for touring and love them. Lightweight, very comfortable, no problems in several trips. Specialised Diverge but Trek are bringing out very similar bike now
data.author: Peter Oag

data.text: I dislike carbon bikes, they make a lot of noise when you ride them, too because the carbon works like a sound board. I don't care about some grams more weight, you have to work a little harder but that's worth it.
data.author: J√∂rg Duurkoop

data.text: thanks Peter. I was starting to question the joy I feel riding mine after reading the thread. I ride EX9.8 and it never fails to impress, one very costly rim failure aside. Ironically proving the threads worth. I'll consider using what I have and accept what may or may not be. I'll sing in the rain . Thanks everyone
data.author: Nicholas Heller

data.text: that sound board you speak of certainly makes finding the source of any squeak difficult to pin point. I've replaced parts only to discover it was a seat squeak all along. Not to mention how unnatural a squeaky bike sounds in a Forest. Eventually I'd be riding alone
data.author: Nicholas Heller

data.text: I always loved it when we would surprise wild animals in the woods because they didn't hear us coming on our tandem. Sadly my partner passed away and I had to sell it.
data.author: J√∂rg Duurkoop

data.text: Keep surprising wild animals J√∂rg. Continue the love in that.. Kia ka ha from nZ
data.author: Nicholas Heller

data.text: Not durable enough for cargo, & no way to repair them out in the field.
data.author: Mike Dannheim

data.text: Carry some J-B weld fere yere carbon fiber repairs. Stuff werks great. I don't see using an old mountain bike as a touring bike, as a cause fere any issues, It the way I went. I have an aluminum frame however. Carbon can be fickle and difficult in all areas of repair. That would be my only concern. But hey, aluminum and steel can fail aswell.
data.author: Kawanta Lewis

data.text: I had a rim failure and that alone gives me pause. Cheers
data.author: Nicholas Heller

data.text: carbon rims ??? I definitely would not go there. I rode a set of spinergies back into he day. Still have them in fact in ma Beach cruiser. I cracked the rear rim all the way through. A little piece of screen and some JB weld, 20 years later, it's still holding.
data.author: Kawanta Lewis

data.text: I've experienced pain through a cracked carbon rim. Food for thought. Cheers
data.author: Nicholas Heller

data.text: a dog day afternoon!
data.author: Nicholas Heller

data.text: cheers Kawanta. There seems to be a bias away from carbon bikes for this style of riding. I'm not convinced bike packing would ever be as torturous as hurtling down mountains. Is there an inherent flaw in these bikes that increases the risk of fail? Do so many frames fail I wonder
data.author: Nicholas Heller

data.text: I've had one carbon fiber bike and it was a road bike. Whut I do have is construction knowledge. Carbon acts more like steal than aluminum. It flexes, well just like steal, over time those flex points will breack. Carbon is a little more fickle in that if it let's say you hit something. Carbon will breack/crack where as metal will not, "usually". But hey man, don't over think it, just get on the bike and go. Peace migo
data.author: Kawanta Lewis

data.text: haha yes. My conclusion is flex or break the only difference is the resulting story ...
data.author: Nicholas Heller

data.text: I chose aluminum, I built the touring bike I have now from a older Marin Juniper Trail hardball mountain bike. I went with a 26 tire because they are more readily available. I chose an aluminum frame because they are stiffer and less likely ta fail. I've had a steel bike fail before. Here is the only pic I have of it.
data.author: Kawanta Lewis

data.text: some satisfaction riding the bike you built aye. Well done
data.author: Nicholas Heller

data.text: That was the idea. It fits me absolutely perfectly. I can ride this bike fere hours on end. I put butterfly handle bars on and love them.
data.author: Kawanta Lewis

data.text: carbon definitely has its critics. It isn't a bad material though. Like you said, it has a good flex to it, it's obviously lighter while retaining most of the properties of steel. It's hard to repair, but I don't know anyone who has smartly chosen a touring bike, that has needed to get their bike repaired on the road. I personally won't buy a carbon bike, but mostly because I just have a romance with classic steel 80s frames. But don't get your underwear in a wad... carbon is a very good choice.
data.author: Ryan Tew

data.text: your words are welcome to my reading eyes. Too many people give aluminum a bad reputation. I'm very happy to see you are doing well with it!
data.author: Ryan Tew

data.text: I'd love to ride with you sometime in the future. Thanks for this post!
data.author: Ryan Tew

data.text: I think it has its place. Steel and carbon ride real similar with in a road bike, and I like both. I have a arthritis all over. I can't do an aluminum road bike, to rough. I have an aluminum road bike with carbon stays. It is nice, the vibration is not bad. My mountain bikes aluminum too. Never had an aluminum bike fail on me. Just sayin. Lol.
data.author: Kawanta Lewis

data.text: you in Arizona ???
data.author: Kawanta Lewis

data.text: getting a bike is like buying shoes. There's plenty of advice out there, but the bike you are comfortable with and enjoy riding is the best!!
data.author: Ryan Tew

data.text: I'm in Louisiana actually, but I've traveled AZ. Is that where you are?
data.author: Ryan Tew

data.text: I have been thinking of a SW tour (TX, NM, AZ, NV)... 2 months in the fall.
data.author: Ryan Tew

data.text: If you have it , lucky you , but if you are buying a forever bike , steel will last forever . They're saying that both high grade aluminum and Carbon Fiber have a life expectancy now .
data.author: Kevin Adams

data.text: without sounding like a carbon snob since owning my current bike I'd be hard pushed to go back to the previous bike although they are both fuels. The other bike was awesome but I found the carbon bike only added to my fun. My times were quicker even during the training wheel period. I was not convinced at first at it's durability but soon overcame that caution. So far it appears bullet proof. However I found out the hard way rims are not always bullet proof. I'd recommend one for sure. Not so sure the price is justified. I bought mine from a friend and was super happy to pay for it
data.author: Nicholas Heller

data.text: Probably won't be a problem but I got anxious about it cracking etc & got a steel bike I find it a more comfortable ride but wouldn't fancy lifting it over any gates compared to my old carbon .
data.author: Kevin Dean

data.text: I‚Äôve always loved touring on carbon‚Ä¶ For several day trips in your local area, I don‚Äôt think there are downsides, if you protect the frame from rubbing luggage. it wasn‚Äôt until I started doing international tours which required me to regularly fly with the bike (in luggage), put it under coach buses, strap it to the top of vans‚Ä¶. That I switched to a more hardy titanium frame. It all depends on what kind of riding you plan to do
data.author: Jessica Luscher

data.text: I guess that being said, consider where it is you want to ride (overseas?), how you‚Äôll pack the bike (high functioning and protective bag, or just a box - important because if you use a real piece of luggage, you have to leave it somewhere and return to get it) what other transport you might need (does the bike need to go in bus cargo?), how easy it will be to bail out if you do need to unexpectedly end your trip (I had a malfunction unrelated to my frame which caused me to hitchhike and take multiple buses to exit the Peru Divide, for example‚Ä¶) anticipating all of these issues is what caused me to replace my carbon gravel bike with a titanium mtb before I rode the Baja Divide, Peru Divide, etc, really for piece of mind
data.author: Jessica Luscher

data.text: law of averages. Thank you for this. You made my mind up. To be fair I'd say changed my mind. I have my time to find a bike more fit in my ways. Kia ka ha Jessica
data.author: Nicholas Heller

data.text: glad to provide help üòÅ
data.author: Jessica Luscher

data.text: . I had a moment with my bike and we both decided on a course of least resistants. I'll change tracks to suit the both of us. I created an urban night trail for MTB in Auckland City. An accident prevented posting a first ride. I'm off the bike until December and very much hooked on urban riding MTB. Perhaps I do the same all over Europe in places where friends and strangers appear. If a bike park happens in my way. I'll ride that too... I'm writing you because I simply love the rare moments of sudden awakening. And thought I'd share (no button intended)... Cheers
data.author: Nicholas Heller
